article.name: Add a TXT Record to Your DNS Records
article.title: Add a TXT Record to Your DNS Records
article.body:
If you're in the process of adding a new root domain to your KSAT console, you’ll need to add a text (TXT) record to your organization’s domain name system (DNS) records. Adding a TXT record to your organization’s DNS records allows KnowBe4 to verify that you own and maintain the domain.

In this article, you’ll learn how to add a TXT record to your organization’s DNS records. For general information about adding root domains or subdomains to your KSAT console, see our Add and Verify Domains article.

Before You Begin

Before you can add a TXT record to your DNS records, you'll need to complete the following steps:

  1. Verify that you have permissions to modify the DNS records for your organization's domain. If you don’t have these permissions, contact the employee in your organization who can modify these records for you.
  2. Identify your domain host or domain name registrar. To learn how to find this information, see the Identify your domain host article from Google.

Adding a TXT Record

First, you’ll need to obtain the TXT record from your KSAT Account Settings. This TXT record will apply to all allowed domains that you add to your KSAT console. To learn how to obtain your TXT record, see our Add and Verify Domains article.

After you've obtained your TXT record, you can add it to your DNS records. The instructions for adding a TXT record will vary depending on your domain host or domain name registrar.

Click the links below to view instructions for a specific domain name registrar or domain host:

Note:If your domain host or domain name registrar is not listed below, we recommend contacting them directly for instructions.
  • Amazon Simple Email Service (SES)
  • Bluehost
  • Cloudflare
  • GoDaddy
  • Google
  • Hover
  • Microsoft
  • Name.com
  • Namecheap
  • United Domains
  • Wix

Once you've added your TXT record to your DNS records, you’ll be ready to verify your domain. For instructions, see our Add and Verify Domains article.
